title: Ductal Carcinoma in Situ Detected on Screening Mammogram
setup_script: A 52-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography showing microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Stereotactic core biopsy reveals high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with comedo necrosis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Obtain history including family history of breast cancer, hormone use, and previous biopsies; perform clinical breast exam.
Discuss the pathology of DCIS and that it is non-invasive but carries risk of progression to invasive cancer.
Order MRI or additional imaging if there is concern for multifocal disease or high breast density.
Explain treatment options: breast conserving surgery (lumpectomy) with radiation versus mastectomy; weigh pros and cons.
Assess candidacy for lumpectomy based on lesion size relative to breast size and patient preference.
Obtain informed consent for lumpectomy; discuss need for sentinel lymph node biopsy if extensive DCIS or planned mastectomy.
Plan surgery with wire or seed localization to excise DCIS with clear margins; send specimens for frozen section if available.
Perform lumpectomy with oncoplastic closure; orient specimen for pathology; excise margins when necessary.
Postoperative management: manage wound, schedule radiation therapy consultation, and discuss endocrine therapy if ER positive.
Review final pathology for margin status; decide on re-excision if margins positive.
Discuss follow-up including yearly mammography and lifestyle modifications to reduce recurrence.
Provide emotional support and resources such as support groups and genetic counseling if indicated.

critical_decision_points: Communicating the nature of DCIS and treatment options clearly.
Determining appropriateness of breast conservation versus mastectomy.
Achieving clear margins during lumpectomy and deciding on sentinel lymph node biopsy.
Coordinating postoperative radiation and endocrine therapy.
Providing psychosocial support and surveillance plan.
